projectDesc.p: "My Dear Elizabeth: Letters from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 1837-1868" is an electronic edition of five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne (1809-1871) to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody (1804-1894).

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Hawthorne letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Hawthorne's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.
The XML and XSL files related to this edition are all available in the KB.

refsDecl.p: The TEI elements for the individual letters that constitute this edition of Sophia Hawthorne's letters are provided with xml:id values that reflect the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: SPH_YYYYMMDD. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars.

The value of @facs elements related to each image that accompanies this edition consist of the filename of the corresponding page image and a "view" designation for pages on which text is written in two or more orientations.

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Her Sister, Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 8 August 1837
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter, Sophia Peabody attempts to correct misunderstandings between herself and her sister Elizabeth regarding Sophia's estimation of Abigail May Alcott [Mrs. Bronson Alcott] and, more generally, the sisters' differing attitudes toward "fault-finding." Before mailing the letter to Elizabeth, Sophia gives it to her sister Mary, who adds her own perspective on the misunderstanding, asking for sympathy and peace as well as communicating her frustrations with both of her sisters.

div.p:
I have just read your long letter.
I cannot wait a moment before disabusing you
of one entirely mistake, which is your impres‐
sion of my estimation of Mrs. Alcott. You never
heard me express for her a want of respect
or love, for from the beginning & through all
I have thought her a sort of sublime phe‐
nomenon — a terrible power made up of
divinest tenderness— vast humanity — infinite
self sacrifice — a perfect juggernaut devotion
to the Right. I have loved her dearly always.
How can you think otherwise.? Don't you remember
at that time my sympathy with her — & afterwards
my writing often to her, & ever since the affectionate
way in which we have ever met.? I have always
felt the utmost tenderness for her. I scarcely
ever saw a person who seemed to me so full
of pathos — amounting to the fearful. I am at a
loss to imagine how you have such an idea in
your mind. Does it not show what complete,
misunderstandings may exist — I never thought her deformed, never moved by earthly passion.

I had a long talk with Mary the other
evening about this discussing of people's faults.
She said she never before understood what
I meant, & she did not believe you did.
It is not that I do not see people do wrong — & that
therefore I necessarily am unjust — but I have
understood Christ to teach that if each one looked
only to his own errors, perhaps there would be justermore just
judgment & greater improvement in individuals.
When he speaks plainly I prefer to understand
him plainly, for I find it the most fruitful
of good. It has not been a personal feeling
for particular persons — for Mr. Alcott for instance,
but this general principle, which would make
me feel the same if a person I never knew
were analysedanalyze & decided upon. I know
that GOD only can know a person truly,
from my own experience, & I know that immense
mistakes are made in sweeping or even in what
seem cool, rational judgments of others.
But as the seeing mind cannot but observe
I have thought that each person had better
not by talking emphasize bad opinions of men — arguing
pronouncing & deciding upon their motives & actions,
which ever must be somewhat in the dark —
but let the opinion be constantly modified
or changed in the mind by the evolving of circumstances &
the influx of more light. Then no one would
be so cruelly wronged as some are — & there
would be more time & room for the interchange
of thought about things which are eternal —
Christ might say Woe unto you, hypocrites! Because
there was no mote in his eye to take out,See Matt. 7: 3-5. & he
could see without clear vision, what was in
man, but it is not so with the less exalted.
I have said to myself Oh let me enjoy & speak
of the good I see —
& be silent of the evil I see.
You have& Mary have thought me morbid about
hearing certain people spoken of — I always knew
this was not the truth. It was not the person
but the thing that I struggled against.
Even when I have mutely listened, I have
always had a mental reservation that perhaps
it was not so — for GOD alone could see the heart —
& comprehend all the grounds upon which it
acted. I can see good in being openeyed
& not acting with a rash confidence — but I
suspect I shall live forever & not see good
in dwelling upon personal faults. For my life
I cannot percieveperceive the least use in talking
about them. I never hear of a great crime
committed that I do not wish I had a hundred
thousand arms & powers to guard the person
from being utterly condemned, because no oneman
can know the tragedy, the struggle, the woe,
the misery of the being's inward life who
transgressed—and it is an infinite comfort to me
always to know that GOD knows all & will accordingly
award with infinite tenderness— & allow for all
want of light. A murder which horrifies the
community never seems to me so dreadful or wrong
in the eye of Heaven as the animadversions of
those who think they are more righteous than the
murderer. Nevertheless, I can s certainly suppose
that to you it may seem quite otherwise about
this matter, & that you do your duty in a way
of proceeding, which with my idea—it would
manifestly be wrong for me to adopt.
I never thought it want of charity in you
or Mary totalk of

because I know it is impossible for an intelligent
mind not to take observations. But to
it has been productive of more good to
this reflect as little as possible upon the shadow
but & I & live & expand in the light & & I feel

GOD will give the increase to both our sowings
wayssince both are followed sown in obedience

I feel myself — when I am unjust to others — or

feel how much better others are then I — but the
contrary never occupies my thoughts. I am
If I have verged to either extreme it has been that

Do not suppose I extend this fault finding face

— for then the two persons being all that

It is bad But to talk & judge of a person

I would

but Christ was even beautiful — & my aim is to do so, as well as true &
good — for I think Beauty is the result of the two. But I never was
aware of seeking beauty in the first place. By keeping my heart

postscript.p:
Sophy has given me this to read
and send, & I hope it is the
last document ^ of the sort that will pas
She wrote it with difficulty
for she had a raging headache
& has been on the bed & dizzy.
When she finished yrou letter she
burst into tears. I told her I
hope that would give her
pleasure — she said it did,
but she could not help crying —
& that you did not understand
her about Mrs. Alcott & c. ‐(what
she has said to you here) I told
her I felt as if all was settled
now, & I think she does
but I did not persist in
talking, for she said she felt
as if her body was just where
it was seven months ago tho'
her mind was in a different
state. Now don't tell her I
told you this about her body, for*
*if you wish to have her tranquil, you must let her alone
more. I believe if you & she have any more cryings
about each other I shall die. I have often wished you
both dead, & I shall never enjoy you
till I think this matter is not to be
alluded to again. I hope you will not
say Alcott for one year if you can help
it, for the word is the touchstone to
all this emotion. There is no temper
in her crying now if there ever was—it
is pure physical agony — but she only apprehends now
that it will be perhaps difficult to appear
natural, at least for a time & that you
will misconstrue that. I have assured
her that you will allow for that, and now
the rest must be left to you. My happiness waits upon
your good judgment. yrou M.
I'm going to send for Harriet & Mrs
Abbot to come & spend a day & a night
Monday or Tuesday —before

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, 11 November 1839
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Sophia describes events surrounding her brother George's last illness, including a visit from Rev. Edward Thomson Taylor.

div.p:
I suppose that Mr. Taylor
2 has
told you of George's 3 perfect frame
of mind — of his experience of
that divine glow which was so
unaccountable — but so sweet &
refreshing to him — & seemed so like
an intimation from GOD that
it was well with him —; but he
would not tell you how like
a tender & strong angel he ^ himself was
to us all — what a wonderful
prayer he offered — which seemed
to bring the host of heaven
down to watch & duly ward -
which brought heaven into
George's chamber & carried us
all as on Dove's wings into
the spiritual world. It was the
most fervid — the most affectionate,
tender & divine uplifting of
soul to the infinite father —
that I ever heard. He prayed for
each — for the Mother, 4 the tender
Mother — who hung around her life
for the Father's 5 manly heart —
for the sister 6 whose duty called
her away — & oh bless — our dear Mary
7
he said — let not that peaceful
stream be disturbed — " he prayed
for the sister present 8 — 'she with
the delicate nerves —' For Aunt
Pickman
9 too he petitioned
heaven — The tears were at
last loosened from my brain
which I had kept back so long
that I began to feel as if they
were accumulating there —
& they flowed down my face
like a summer rain without
convulsion. After he rose
from his knees, George stretched
out his arms & Mr. Taylor
clasped him to his heart in
a long, long embrace — Every
moment ejaculating "The Lord
bless you! Bless you! Bless you!"
in such a thrilling tone that
it seemed as if blessings must
come in legions at the call —
George's thin white hands were
so firmly fastened round his neck
that I thought he would never
let the angel go — even after he
had blessed him — but at last
he relaxed his hold. Then Mr
Taylor turned to me & took both
hands. Be strong said he. It is
very pleasant on the other side. Be
quiet alike a May morning.
He came with me into my room.
Oh George is a perfect lamb! A
perfect lamb. He is moonlight —
so clear — mild — I would not but
have seen him for the world. It
was worth coming just to look at
him. He never looked so handsome
in his life. There is no distortion
there. All is right. All is right.
I cannot tell you all he said now.
Oh he is the most helpful — the
divinest spirit — is he not?
George said there could not be such
a prayer conceived of. Mr. Taylor
is no sham — he said.
George is very much revived this
afternoon. He had not a bad
chill this morning — hardly any — &
yesterday it was
two hours long
Mary came today & staid two hours
I carried her your letter this afternoon
& she had receivedrecieved no harm.
George thinks it would not be
right for you to come on
Wednesday. He thinks of
every thing in all relations
with exactest precision.
Yesterday he wandered a
little several times, & this
afternoon while I was rubbing
his arm, he was saying
something — & then said something
I did not hear. What did
you say I asked. It belies
was nothing to the purpose, he
replied. I was wandering.
I never saw such clearness. He
looks from some high place
even upon his aberrations.
I can write no more now
I receivedrecieved a blessed refreshment
yesterday P.M. beside Mr
Taylor, a long — closely written letter

titleStmt.title: Letter from Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to Elizabeth Palmer Peabody, January 8th, 1859
titleStmt.author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Sophia and family are in Rome recovering from sickness. The family plans to stay in Rome for February, March, and half of April. From there the famly will travel to Venice, northern Italian cities, Geneva, and Paris. Sophia informs Elizabeth on the status of her friends in Italy.
